title: Bug: Copilot Custom Provider breaks OpenAI-compatible APIs by mangling base URL
body:
---

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->  

<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->  

<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->  

<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->  

<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->  

<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->  

<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->  

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

* VS Code Version: **Insiders build (September 2025)**
* OS Version: **\[Windows 10 + 19045.6332]**

---

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open VS Code Insider → GitHub Copilot Chat → Custom Provider / API Key settings.
2. Set provider base URL to:

   ```
   https://api.z.ai/api/coding/paas/v4
   ```

   (You have a Z.AI API key, model, etc. that are OpenAI-compatible.)
3. Trigger a chat/completion prompt.
4. Inspect in the request metadata: the full URL used is malformed (suffix `/chat/completions` appended incorrectly or doubled) → request fails.

---

### Expected Behavior

* Because Z.AI is OpenAI-compatible, setting the base URL to `https://api.z.ai/api/coding/paas/v4` should let Copilot correctly send requests to `https://api.z.ai/api/coding/paas/v4/chat/completions`.
* The base URL should not be modified incorrectly by Copilot.

---

### Actual Behavior

* Copilot mangles the URL (adds or duplicates suffix), which breaks the communication with Z.AI. Requests do not reach properly.

---

### Why This Matters

* This blocks use of OpenAI-compatible providers (like Z.AI) even though they follow the spec.
* The “Bring Your Own Key / Custom Provider” feature in Copilot should support these without needing workarounds.
* Other documentation suggests custom endpoints / BYOK support is possible. See:

  * [GitHub](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues/7518?utm_source=chatgpt.com) issue “Add custom OpenAI endpoint configuration (Base URL & Model Parameter)” ([GitHub][1])
  * Microsoft’s docs on *Custom API Keys / Language Models / Reusable Prompt Files* under Copilot customization. ([[Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/customization/overview?utm_source=chatgpt.com)][2])

---

title: Allow Users to Set the Default Model for Copilot Chat

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, Copilot Chat allows me to select from multiple models (including Claude Sonnet), but I have to manually choose my preferred model every time I start a new chat session. There is no setting to change the default chat model.

Request:
Please add a user setting (for example, github.copilot.selectedChatModel) that lets users specify their preferred default model for Copilot Chat. This would make the experience more efficient for those who consistently use a model other than the current default.

Thank you!

title: The "Ask MongoDB Copilot" feature from the MongoDB extensions, deletes the entire copilot chats history
body:
When I (mostly by mistake) use the "Ask MongoDB Copilot" option from the MongoDB extension, it opens a new Copilot chat, but the entire history of other Copilot chats (accessible from the clock icon "Show chats...") gets completely deleted. There’s no way to recover them. That’s really bad — hours of work disappear instantly.

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.32.2025091701
- VS Code Version: 1.105.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 11 (26100.4946)
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent Mode
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 5-mini:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a project
2. Start a chat with the agent
3. Install the mongodb extensions 
4. You'd need to connect to a mongodb db, the easiest way is to install it locally via docker
5. At database or collection level, click the "github copilot logo" 
6. A new chat with the MongoDB agent is opened but any other chat disappears
7. Open the "show chat..." icon and see that there's no trace of any other chat anymore

title: MCP Server Request is not Initlializing for SSE or HTTP connection after redirecting back to VS Code
body:
Type: Bug MCP Server Request is not Initlializing for SSE or HTTP connection after redirecting back to VS Code This problem arises when you are trying to authenticate with MCP server through OAUTH2.0 Steps to reproduce this - Add mcp json with mcp server url and type - start the server so it will open your browser with authentication url. - once you have logged in and allow to the server it will redirect you back to the vs code - The expected behaviour should be it has to connect to the mcp server and able to fetch tools and prompts etc but it showing 'Waiting for server to respond to `initialize` request...' title: Missing play/pause chat  button we got no way to stop the copilot while is taking actions  or to pause them github.copilot-chat Version 0.31.0
body:
I don` know if is a bug or you removed the play/pause button in purpose. We need that button, there is no way in certain situations when you try to stop the model doing some actions to do so !  That button help pause at least and change the conversation or resolve some issues manually, plus that now you cannot change at all the direction in witch the model is going you have the only option to do bad things and then to correct them manually that`s not good.

title: AI features to be moved to an extension
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Visual Studio Code is supposed to be a lightweight and fast editor that users can customise via extensions. There are already extensions for Github copilot for those users that want it, yet the vanilla installation of the editor not only has been including these features for a while but with each release they are more prominent and activated by default.
 
This is a feature request to move all of this to an extension, and if not, at the very minimum have the default for "Chat: Disable AI Features" be True so that they are hidden unless the user wants to see them.

title: Improve Copilot UX in VS Code: reduce babysitting (automatic retries, allow-all option, sound notifications)

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

The current Copilot experience in VS Code is often frustrating because it demands too much manual babysitting. A few specific pain points:

### Problems that ruin the experience

* **Retry fatigue:** If there are connection issues, I have to click **Retry** repeatedly — sometimes up to 20 times for a single request. This is a deal breaker. Retries should be automatic.
* **Repeated “Always Allow”:** I have to confirm “Always Allow” every time. There should be a copilot-wide option like “always allow everything” so I can focus on doing important things like crafting design and architecture instead of constant confirmations.

### Suggestions / Nice-to-have

* **Sound notifications when Copilot is done**
* **Sound notifications when Copilot stalled needs attention**

Sound notifications should be made both when the VS Code window is focused or not, so I can hear them even if I’m working in a different window or walked away from the laptop.

---

### Environment

* **VS Code version:** 1.104.0 (user setup)
* **Copilot extension version:** 1.372.0
* **OS:** Windows11
* **Network conditions:** Stable home Wi-Fi

title: Replace chat history header and icon with accessible link in empty state
body:
This PR replaces the "History" title and icon button in the chat empty state with a new "Chat history..." link that appears beneath the history list items.

## Changes Made

**Before:** The chat empty state displayed a "History" header with an icon button that opened the chat history picker.

**After:** The header and icon are removed, and a new "Chat history..." link appears below the list of recent chat items. The link triggers the same `workbench.action.chat.history` command.

## Key Improvements

- **Better UX**: The link placement below the history items feels more natural and less cluttered
- **Accessibility**: The link is properly tabbable with `role="link"` and responds to both Enter and Space keys
- **Consistency**: Uses VS Code's standard link styling with `--vscode-textLink-foreground` color
- **Efficiency**: Early exit when no history exists instead of creating and removing DOM elements

## Implementation Details

- Modified `renderWelcomeHistorySection()` in `chatWidget.ts` to remove header creation
- Added new link element with proper accessibility attributes and event handlers
- Added CSS styling for `.chat-welcome-history-more` class
- Maintained existing visibility logic: link only appears when `chat.emptyState.history.enabled` is true AND history items exist
- Added localization key `chat.history.more` for "Chat history..."

## Testing

- TypeScript compilation passes without errors
- CodeQL security analysis shows no vulnerabilities
- Functionality remains identical to the previous icon button behavior
- Keyboard navigation and screen reader compatibility verified

The change is minimal and surgical, affecting only the UI presentation while preserving all existing functionality and accessibility requirements.

title: Remove text label from Add Context button in chat input, show only centered paperclip icon
body:
## Summary

Successfully modified the 'Add Context' button in VS Code's chat input to remove the text label and show only the paperclip icon as requested.

### Changes Made

- [x] **Modified AddFilesButton class** in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatInputPart.ts`:
  - Changed constructor options from `icon: false, label: true` to `icon: true, label: false`
  - Removed the `updateLabel()` method that was manually rendering icon + text
  - Fixed unused imports (`renderLabelWithIcons`, `assertType`)

- [x] **Updated CSS styling** in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/media/chat.css`:
  - Fixed icon centering by targeting the correct DOM element (`.action-label`)
  - Used flexbox with `align-items: center` and `justify-content: center` on the label element
  - Added `!important` declarations to override conflicting styles
  - **Updated dimensions to 20x20px** to match the visual height of attached context items
  - Resolved box-sizing differences between attach button and attached context items
  - Kept the chip-like border styling as requested

- [x] **Preserved functionality and accessibility**:
  - Button still uses the same action ID (`workbench.action.chat.attachContext`)
  - Tooltip and aria-label remain unchanged ("Add Context..." + keyboard shortcut)
  - Keyboard shortcut (Ctrl/Cmd + /) still works
  - Button functionality is completely preserved

### Technical Details

- TypeScript compilation: ✅ 0 errors
- Security scan (CodeQL): ✅ No issues found
- Icon is now properly centered both vertically and horizontally
- **Height alignment fixed**: Button now matches the visual height of attached context items
- Resolved CSS conflicts from existing `.action-item.chat-attachment-button .action-label` rule
- Fixed box-sizing mismatch that caused height differences

### Visual Result

The button now appears as a clean 20x20px square with:
- Paperclip icon (Codicon.attach) perfectly centered both vertically and horizontally
- **Properly aligned with attached context items** - same visual height
- Chip-like border matching other attachment tokens

title: Add Dynamic HTML Chat View to Replace Accessible View for Screen Reader Users

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: accessibility
labels.description: Keyboard, mouse, ARIA, vision, screen readers (non-specific) issues

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Type: Feature Request # **Add Dynamic HTML Chat View to Replace Accessible View for Screen Reader Users** ### **Subtitle** Eliminate the static Accessible View in favor of an integrated, scrollable, copyable chat transcript with headings, actionable links, sound cues, and seamless F6 toggling — dramatically improving accessibility, efficiency, and user experience. --- ## Triage Summary This proposal replaces the current static Accessible View used for chat responses with a dynamic, scrollable HTML transcript view inside the chat panel. It introduces headings for quick navigation, actionable links/buttons, copy/paste support, polite live updates, an optional sound cue for “Working…”, and seamless F6 toggling between chat input and transcript without losing place. Shipping it behind an experimental setting (`"chat.experimentalHTMLAccessibleView"`) would allow early testing and feedback from screen reader users, helping close a major accessibility gap and set a new standard for inclusive developer tooling. --- ## Motivation has built a reputation as one of the most accessible and inclusive developer environments available. The proposed change continues that leadership by addressing one of the last major friction points for screen reader users: accessing chat responses. Replacing the static, modal **Accessible View** with a **dynamic, scrollable, interactive HTML chat view** aligns perfectly with VS Code’s goals of efficiency, inclusivity, and seamless productivity. It would modernize the chat experience while preserving the product’s commitment to first-class accessibility for all. --- ## Steps to Reproduce Current Problem 1. Open a chat session (such as with ) inside VS Code. 2. Submit a prompt and wait for a response. 3. Attempt to read the response with a screen reader. 4. Notice that: * You must open **Accessible View** to read the content. * The response opens in a **separate static document** instead of remaining inline in the chat panel. * Links and buttons are presented as **plain text** and are not actionable. * There is **no heading structure** to navigate between prompts and responses. * Copy/paste is cumbersome or unreliable. * The screen reader announces **“Working …”** which often collides with other tooling announcements. * Returning to the chat panel closes the Accessible View and loses your position in both. --- ## Expected vs Actual Behavior | | Expected Behavior | Actual Behavior | | ----------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------- | | Reading responses | Can be read directly in the chat panel | Must open a separate Accessible View | | Navigation | Continuous scrolling and heading navigation across responses | Static single-response document, no heading structure | | Links and buttons | Exposed as focusable actionable elements | Shown as plain text, not actionable | | Copy/paste | Standard text selection and copy supported | Inconsistent or blocked | | Announcements | Optional soft sound cue for “Working …” | Spoken “Working …” interrupts other announcements | | Focus behavior | F6 toggles between chat input and transcript without losing place | Opening/closing Accessible View loses focus/position | --- ## Summary Currently, screen reader users must open a static Accessible View to read chat responses, which disrupts workflow, prevents continuous scrolling, and makes links and buttons unusable. I propose adding a dynamic HTML-based chat view inside the chat panel itself that allows scrolling, text selection, copy/paste, and proper heading-based navigation, while rendering links and buttons as actionable elements. It would support polite live updates, replace the disruptive “Working …” spoken announcement with an optional soft sound cue, and allow quick F6-based toggling between the chat input area and this transcript view without losing place, greatly improving accessibility and efficiency. --- ## Describe the feature you’d like to request Introduce a **dynamic HTML-based view** for chat responses that: * Stays inside the chat panel (no context switch to Accessible View) * Supports **continuous scrolling, selection, and copy/paste** * Renders **links and buttons as focusable actionable elements** * Uses **headings for user prompts and responses** to enable quick screen reader navigation * Provides **polite live updates** without stealing focus * Allows **F6 to switch between the chat input area and the transcript view** while **preserving focus position** in both places * **Replaces “Working …” spoken announcements with an optional soft non-verbal sound cue** to avoid collisions with other screen reader or tooling announcements --- ## Describe the problem this feature would solve **Current experience:** * Requires opening **Accessible View** to read chat responses, which takes users out of the chat panel. * Returning to the chat panel requires closing Accessible View, which is disruptive and disorienting. * The view is static, so users cannot scroll continuously through multiple responses. * Text is often difficult to copy/paste from. * **Links and buttons are presented as plain text**, not actionable elements, and cannot be activated by keyboard. * There is **no heading structure** to distinguish user prompts from assistant responses, preventing fast navigation with screen reader heading commands. * Live streaming responses sometimes **steal focus**, and the **“Working …” spoken announcement interrupts** other screen reader or tooling output. **Resulting impact:** * Significantly reduced efficiency and productivity for screen reader and keyboard-only users. * Difficult to navigate, copy, or act on content within the chat experience. --- ## Describe the benefits this feature would bring * Provides a **single, continuous reading surface** for all chat responses directly in the chat panel. * Allows **standard navigation, selection, and copy/paste** like a typical webpage. * Makes **links and buttons usable and discoverable** by keyboard and screen reader users. * Provides **heading-based navigation** (e.g. `

` for user prompts, `

` for assistant responses), allowing quick jumps between messages. * Eliminates **context switching and disorientation** caused by Accessible View. * **Soft sound cue** avoids announcement collisions while still giving progress feedback. * **F6 toggling** enables smooth movement between the compose area and the reading area without losing position in either. --- ## Additional context **Implementation suggestions:** * Use `main` landmark for the transcript region and `aria-live="polite"` for streamed tokens. * Provide visible focus indicators and semantic `` and `

labels.description: Automatic model selection

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

## Background 

The current experimental Auto model selection does not take the current selected models in the model picker into account. 

The reason for this feature request is in some workspace or type of work I would like to select which models to should be available for copilot to pick out of. This could be due to

- Selecting right models for the nature of the work

- Managing costs etc

## Suggestions 

1. Consider the selected models in model picker when doing the auto model selection. This will be a good start. 

2. Ability configure which models to consider for Auto Model selection, which can be configured per workspace basis.

title: Add drag-and-drop download functionality to the SSH Explorer.
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, the SSH Explorer supports drag-and-drop uploads, but not downloads. For example, when you need to download an entire project to your local machine, the current method requires selecting multiple files, right-clicking, and manually specifying filenames one by one, which is inefficient. I hope to add support for directly dragging remote files or folders from the SSH Explorer to the local file system to initiate downloads.

title: Implement double-click to create new chat session in Chat Sessions view
body:
Fixes #264515

This PR implements the ability to double-click in empty space within the Chat Sessions view to create a new chat session, following the same UX pattern as the Explorer view.

## Changes

Added a double-click event handler to the Chat Sessions tree that:
- Detects when empty space is clicked (`e.element === null`)
- Respects the `workbench.list.scrollByPage` configuration to avoid conflicts with page scrolling
- Executes the existing `workbench.action.chat.open` command to create a new chat session

## Implementation Details

The implementation follows the exact same pattern as the Explorer view's double-click handler:

```typescript
this._register(this.tree.onMouseDblClick(e => {
    // If empty space is clicked, and not scrolling by page enabled #173261
    const scrollingByPage = this.configurationService.getValue<boolean>('workbench.list.scrollByPage');
    if (e.element === null && !scrollingByPage) {
        // click in empty area -> create a new chat session #264515
        this.commandService.executeCommand('workbench.action.chat.open');
    }
}));
```

This ensures consistency across VS Code's interface and provides users with an intuitive way to create new chat sessions without having to locate the "+" button.

## Testing

- ✅ TypeScript compilation passes with no errors
- ✅ Layer validation checks pass  
- ✅ Security vulnerability scan shows no issues
- ✅ Code follows established VS Code patterns and conventions

The change is minimal and surgical, adding only 10 lines of code without modifying any existing functionality.

title: Extensions: Add visible restart icon in Extensions view header

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: **Problem** When an extension requires a restart, users currently need to scroll through the **Installed** list in the Extensions view to find it. - There is no global indicator that a restart is required. - The “Update All Extensions” option exists, but there is **no equivalent for restart.** - Users often miss the restart prompt or waste time scrolling through the list. **Proposal** Add a small icon/indicator next to **Installed** in the Extensions view header. - The icon would only appear when one or more extensions require a restart. - Clicking it would provide a “**Restart extensions**” action. **Why it’s useful** - Makes restart requirements visible at a glance. - Eliminates the need to scroll through the Installed list. - Complements the existing “Update All Extensions” option. **Mockup (conceptual)** Something like this (not final design, just to illustrate placement): `Installed [🔄] ` Where [🔄] appears only if one or more extensions require restart. _(Exact icon/design is up to the team — this is just to show placement.)_
